content: <metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>Idaho DEQ with Research Triangle Institude (RTI) 2001</origin><pubdate>20101006</pubdate><title>2010 Final Integrated Report 305B for Idaho</title><edition>Final - 2010</edition><geoform Sync="TRUE">vector digital data</geoform><serinfo><sername>WBAG, 305B</sername><issue>Second Edition</issue></serinfo><pubinfo><pubplace>Boise, Idaho</pubplace><publish>Idaho Department of Environmental Quality</publish></pubinfo><othercit>Based upon 100K USGS NHD Linework</othercit><lworkcit><citeinfo><onlink>http://www2.state.id.us/deq/water/surface_water/wbag/WBAG2001_Front_Matter-Sec_6.pdf</onlink></citeinfo></lworkcit><ftname Sync="TRUE">ID305B_2010_STREAMS</ftname><onlink>http://global.deq.idaho.gov/Website/wq2010</onlink><onlink>http://www.deq.idaho.gov/water/data_reports/surface_water/monitoring/2010_draft.cfm</onlink><onlink>http://mapcase.deq.idaho.gov/wq1010</onlink><onlink>http://www.deq.idaho.gov/water-quality/surface-water/monitoring-assessment/integrated-report.aspx</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>Sections 305(b) and 314 of the Clean Water Act (CWA) require states, territories, and authorized tribes to provide biennial reports to EPA on the condition of waters within their boundaries. EPA regulations at 40 CFR 130.7 require states to provide biennial submissions of impaired waters lists. EPA provides guidance on these reports in a way that supports the Agency's strategy for achieving a broad-scale, national inventory of water quality conditions. The guidance is from EPA to states, territories, authorized tribes, and interstate commissions ("jurisdictions") to help states prepare and submit Section 305(b) reports to EPA. Use of the integrated report (IR) format provides jurisdictions a recommended reporting format and suggested content to be used in developing a single document that integrates the reporting requirements of Sections 303(d), 305(b), and 314. This format allows jurisdictions to report on the water quality standards attained for all waters, document the availability of data and information for each segment, identify certain trends in water quality conditions, and set priorities for protecting and restoring the health of the nation's aquatic resources.  Section 305(b) of the Clean Water Act requires each state to conduct  water quality surveys to determine a water body's overall health,  including whether or not basic uses are being met. States, tribes, and  other jurisdictions define appropriate uses for a waterbody and  incorporate these uses into water quality standards that are approved  by EPA. Water body uses include aquatic life protection, fish and  shellfish production, drinking water supply, swimming, boating,  fishing, and agricultural irrigation, among others.</abstract><purpose>The Clean Water Act protects and preserves water quality in the United States by protecting the uses designated for specific waterbodies.  The results of the 305(b) assessments are not raw data but rather statements of the degree to which each water body supports the uses designated in state or tribal water quality standards.  For example, two rivers may have the exact same chemical and physical makeup, but one of the rivers may be considered as impaired because of different water quality standards</purpose><supplinf> Each state and  tribe collects these assessments and extensive programmatic  information in a 305(b) report, a document usually involving  information from multiple agencies. Reports are submitted to  EPA every two years. Data in 305(b) reports reflect water quality  conditions for two years prior to the year of the reporting cycle.  When states identify impaired water bodies through  305(b) assessments, they are required to identify the waters and to develop total maximum daily loads (TMDLs) for them, with oversight  from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.  Through the TMDL process,  methods are implemented to improve a water body's  status to fully supporting.  Additional information on the TMDL process is available through the EPA Office of Water TMDL web site. </supplinf><langdata Sync="TRUE">en</langdata></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>20111006</caldate><time>12:00 PM</time></sngdate></timeinfo><current>20111006</current></timeperd><status><progress>Complete</progress><update>Every 2 years</update></status><spdom><bounding><westbc Sync="TRUE">-117.530945</westbc><eastbc Sync="TRUE">-110.665395</eastbc><northbc Sync="TRUE">49.039492</northbc><southbc Sync="TRUE">41.929951</southbc></bounding><lboundng><leftbc Sync="TRUE">2241685.000000</leftbc><rightbc Sync="TRUE">2743925.000000</rightbc><topbc Sync="TRUE">1982069.666667</topbc><bottombc Sync="TRUE">1196918.000000</bottombc></lboundng></spdom><keywords><theme><themekt>ID 303D</themekt><themekey>Water quality Standards</themekey><themekey>305B</themekey><themekey>Beneficial Uses</themekey><themekey>Impaired Waters</themekey><themekey>303D</themekey><themekey>WBAG 2000</themekey><themekey>ADB</themekey><themekey>2010 Reporting Cycle</themekey><themekey>TMDL</themekey><themekey>CATEGORY 5</themekey></theme><theme><themekey>Streams</themekey></theme><place><placekey>Idaho</placekey><placekey>Streams</placekey><placekey>Waterbodies</placekey></place></keywords><accconst>None</accconst><useconst>Scale and Resolution for USGS 1:100,000 Scale Data</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><cntorgp><cntorg>ID DEQ</cntorg><cntper>Nicole Deinarowicz</cntper></cntorgp><cntpos>305B Program Manager</cntpos><cntvoice>208 343-0591</cntvoice><cntemail>Nicole.Deinarowicz@deq.idaho.gov</cntemail><hours>8:00 -
